Notes

Overview

Overview
This practical module aims to enhance and develop practical and analytical skills related to the Biosciences by building on experiences gained in previous practical modules. This module will expand on core techniques and practical skills introduced at previous levels of study and develop quantitative and qualitative research practices, data handling and critical analyses applied to experimental research problems. Students will learn the fundamental principles of experimental design and the essential statistical and mathematical methods necessary for assessment and communication of practical experiments. Within this module, students will be able to tailor their practical learning to focus on research problems associated with their programme of study or fields of interest.

The module comprises of physical practical sessions alongside introductory plenary lectures and workshops, using active-learning delivery methods to ensure students can understand, synthesise, evaluate and communicate their research findings.  This practical will be assessed via three methods: 1) a computer-based assessment to assess understanding of quantitative and computational skills, 2) a group research output focused on experimental design and 3) analyses of data and a written scientific report to assess communication of research outputs through scientific writing.
Educational Aims
The aims of this module are:

1. To develop and enhance experimental and practical skills relevant to the disciplines of Biosciences, including key experimental design principles.

2. To enhance students’ acquisition of fundamental research skills; including information gathering, scientific data collection, report writing and statistical analyses.

3. To enable students to analyse and interpret scientific data from different types of experiment and communicate the results

4. To enhance digital fluency, including development of coding skills, data visualisation and computational analyses.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This practical skills module is designed to give you hands-on experience in a range of essential laboratory techniques, building on foundational practical skills developed in the first year of study. From protein purification to nucleic acid quantification and the use of general model systems, this module covers a variety of techniques that you need to further your practical development within the breadth of the Biosciences disciplines.

Through a series of interactive experimental sessions and live synchronous workshops, you will gain practical experience in a variety of analytical and quantitative experimental practices. You will also learn the underpinning knowledge behind some of the methodologies and the intricacies of experimental design, all the while supplementing your wider theoretical learning through experimental application of techniques to tackle problems across the Biosciences disciplines. Students will learn how to analyse collected data and communicate the findings effectively, with the opportunity to apply your newly acquired skills to research projects tailored towards your programme and fields of interest. This module will be assessed via a computer-based assessment to assess understanding of quantitative and computational skills, a group research output focused on experimental design and a written scientific report to assess communication of research outputs through scientific writing.

This module will expand your laboratory skills and allow the advancement of practical experiences in a range of essential techniques and equip you with the skills and knowledge you need to prepare you for your honours dissertation projects.
Outline Syllabus
Topic 1: Dissection practical - dissecting tissue relevant to subject specific disciplines, non-exhaustive examples might include: muscle for biomedical sciences, or fish gills for zoology students.

Topic 2: Immunological Assays and immunostaining

Topic 3: Protein Extraction and purification

Topic 4: Western Blotting

Topic 5: Cell Biology Techniques - for example treatment of cell cultures with pharmacological agents and plate based assays.

Topic 6: RNA Extraction. Covering topics such as theory of extraction protocols, RNA quality control and CDNA library creation

Topic 7: Reporter Gene Systems. Use of reporter gene systems in model organisms, such as but not included to plants

Topic 8: Quantitative RNA methods to tackle biological problems. Covering topics such as, but not limited to qPCR, RNAseq.

Topic 9: Cell Imaging. Covering topics such as fluorescent cell imaging


Statistical, data interpretation & data visualisation skills to be implemented may include topics such as (but not limited to):


Topic 1: Data visualisation

Topic 2: t-tests

Topic 3: ANOVA

Topic 4: Correlation

Topic 5: Linear regression

Topic 6: Chi-square

Topic 7: Non-parametric tests
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching Method 1

Lectures: Synchronous research focused lectures will cover introductory material and context to the practical skills and application of taught & experimental skills. Also incorporate application of numeracy & wider transferable skills to practical problem solving.

Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 2

Laboratory Work: F2F practical sessions designed to develop & enhance laboratory/experimental skills, including group working.
Demonstrators provide real-time feedback in laboratory practicals.

Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 3

Interactive Materials: Interactive virtual lab resources, simulations and videos that allow students to familiarise themselves with different lab skills and use equipment and scientific procedures within their own time and space, allowing for inclusivity & diversity.

Attendance Recorded: No, engagement monitored

Teaching Method 4

Asynchronous lecture recordings: Introduce applied quantitative skills to practical problem solving. To include a variety of data handling, statistical and data visualisation methodologies.

Attendance Recorded: No, engagement monitored

Teaching Method 5

Workshop Sessions: Academic led sessions that support problem-based learning approach on implementing data analysis, interpretation and visualisation skills. During the workshops, students may engage in smaller groups discussions and research activities on a specific topic related to the module content. Students will be assigned to smaller breakout groups within a larger computer-based teaching room. These comprise multiple sessions of active learning which focus on the assessment tasks/real world research, data analysis and simulations which will be delivered in a computer practical format.
Formative feedback is given to students in assessment workshops. Demonstrators facilitate feedback, and peer learning. Demonstrators will provide real-time feedback in assessment workshops. Students will also use online discussion boards both within and outside the session.

Attendance Recorded: Yes

The student directed learning element of the module will involve directed reading, completion of workbooks, accessing online resources, searching the literature and critically appraising articles. This will require adaptability & organisational skills.

Liverpool Curriculum and the Liverpool Hallmarks are at the centre of this module as evidenced by the cohesive research connected programme we have designed where learning outcomes will be evaluated with authentic assessments that directly relate to activities performed by professional experts in the field. This module contributes to programmes which are specifically designed to support students for future careers in Biosciences:

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists in the breadth of fields of life sciences to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with evidence-based publications of recent clinical, biotechnological and scientific research and application-based conceptualisation, where wider application of practical skills will be demonstrated. Practical tailored to specific research areas of interest, allowing interaction with world class researchers at the fore of scientific breakthrough and development to tackle biological, medical and technological challenges.

Inclusivity and accessibility: Development of practical experience in order to be accessible and inclusive for all individuals. Self-directed learning, using interactive resources will allow students to prepare for sessions and gain understanding of practical techniques before attending. Resource templates use accessible design schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans.

Active learning: Practical and experimental techniques within the biosciences are paramount to active learning through observation, skill acquisition and application. Continual feedback provided to students by staff, demonstrators and peers alike allow students to assess the extent of their learning and continually develop. Collaborative discussion and interpretation of practical methods and their application to wider science fosters deeper learning. Furthermore, group working in diverse teams of students from across the department allow students to gain insights in to broader perspectives and communicate findings from a multidisciplinary perspective.

Authentic assessment: There are three assessment components. The experimental design assessment requires students showcase their aptitude for practical skills and experimental design, continual learning, data analyses and visualisation and development and appreciation of the theoretical principles applied to Biosciences challenges. Online computational assessment will allow students to implement theoretical knowledge of quantitative biology and computational skills that supplement experimental practices, in order to tackle scientific problems related to wider fields of Biosciences. The use of student derived data to problem solve will be representative of real-world analytical techniques required in most career pathways. The Written scientific report is highly authentic for practical application and offers a comprehensive assessment of specialist knowledge and understanding of practical skills, the methodological processes and how they may interlink, whilst promoting presentation in a concise manner.

Confidence: Confidence is developed continuously throughout the module. Lectures are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. Practical sessions involve collaborative groupwork and experimental learning. Learners work as part of a team to plan and carry out complex technical work, under expert supervision. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise. Successfully completing a practical session builds confidence in technical skills and provides students with an awareness of good lab practice, risk assessment and safety when working in a practical environment.

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. Learners have access to advanced digital resources, programmes and analytical tools that will assist in the undertaking of data analyses. These are used as part of both lab based practical analyses and independent learning to consolidate practical and theoretical knowledge. Digital technology is embedded into practical teaching with the use of experimental applications, methodologies and computational practices that learners can explore in their own time. Furthermore, physical workshops will allow students to showcase their understand and application of quantitative tools and statistical methodologies for each of their collected datasets. Assessment activity also required students to develop competency with digital technology in order to effectively analyse data, communicate findings and present ideas/concepts.

Global citizenship: Biosciences is a globally connected professional community. Learning and assessment activities embed values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation and use scientific cases of diverse and underrepresented communities, focus on sustainable practices within the lab and field environment, whilst focusing on wider international collaboration in order to achieve goals. There is a strong ethical focus within the school that empowers learners to take personal responsibility for human impact of their actions, with focus on practical related ethics.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via three assessment components.
Variety of modes of assessment are employed keeping in view inclusivity and diversity.

The mode of assessments include:

SAQ exam – online, SAS Managed. Computer Assessment based on Campus (40%). Resit allowed. Students will use advanced digital resources, programmes and analytical tools to assist in data analyses. (Digital fluency and Authentic assessment- Liverpool Curriculum).

Group Scientific Research output (20%) based on skills acquired in practical sessions, (Authentic assessment- Liverpool Curriculum). Potential for negotiated assessment to include: conference style poster presentation, oral presentation, written scientific report performed as a group to showcase experimental design, knowledge application, quantitative data analyses and research communications. Resit allowed.

Written Individual Scientific Report: (weighting 40%) 1500 word written report detailing experimental processes, methodologies, theoretical knowledge and data analyses undertaken within practical sessions (Research connected teaching - Liverpool Curriculum). Resit allowed

Formative feedback is given to students in assessment workshops. Demonstrators facilitate feedback, and peer learning. Demonstrators will provide real-time feedback in assessment workshops.
Demonstrators also provide real-time feedback in laboratory practicals.

Feedback will be provided to all assessments. Pass mark for all assessments is 40%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

Resit strategy: Resit opportunity will be given to the assessments specified where a resit is available and will have similar format and content as the original assessment, but with substantial revision required and will be submitted during the reassessment window and capped at 40% (pass mark).

Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment. Details on the assessments are on the table below.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Intermediary Practical Skills in Biosciences 2025-26

Org Unit:Biosciences
Level:Level 5
Credits:15
Module Code:BIOS203
Delivery:Liverpool campus · Semester 1

Notes

Overview

Overview
This practical module aims to enhance and develop practical and analytical skills related to the Biosciences by building on experiences gained in previous practical modules. This module will expand on core techniques and practical skills introduced at previous levels of study and develop quantitative and qualitative research practices, data handling and critical analyses applied to experimental research problems. Students will learn the fundamental principles of experimental design and the essential statistical and mathematical methods necessary for assessment and communication of practical experiments. Within this module, students will be able to tailor their practical learning to focus on research problems associated with their programme of study or fields of interest.

The module comprises of physical practical sessions alongside introductory plenary lectures and workshops, using active-learning delivery methods to ensure students can understand, synthesise, evaluate and communicate their research findings.  This practical will be assessed via three methods: 1) a computer-based assessment to assess understanding of quantitative and computational skills, 2) a group research output focused on experimental design and 3) analyses of data and a written scientific report to assess communication of research outputs through scientific writing.
Educational Aims
The aims of this module are:

1. To develop and enhance experimental and practical skills relevant to the disciplines of Biosciences, including key experimental design principles.

2. To enhance students’ acquisition of fundamental research skills; including information gathering, scientific data collection, report writing and statistical analyses.

3. To enable students to analyse and interpret scientific data from different types of experiment and communicate the results

4. To enhance digital fluency, including development of coding skills, data visualisation and computational analyses.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This practical skills module is designed to give you hands-on experience in a range of essential laboratory techniques, building on foundational practical skills developed in the first year of study. From protein purification to nucleic acid quantification and the use of general model systems, this module covers a variety of techniques that you need to further your practical development within the breadth of the Biosciences disciplines.

Through a series of interactive experimental sessions and live synchronous workshops, you will gain practical experience in a variety of analytical and quantitative experimental practices. You will also learn the underpinning knowledge behind some of the methodologies and the intricacies of experimental design, all the while supplementing your wider theoretical learning through experimental application of techniques to tackle problems across the Biosciences disciplines. Students will learn how to analyse collected data and communicate the findings effectively, with the opportunity to apply your newly acquired skills to research projects tailored towards your programme and fields of interest. This module will be assessed via a computer-based assessment to assess understanding of quantitative and computational skills, a group research output focused on experimental design and a written scientific report to assess communication of research outputs through scientific writing.

This module will expand your laboratory skills and allow the advancement of practical experiences in a range of essential techniques and equip you with the skills and knowledge you need to prepare you for your honours dissertation projects.
Outline Syllabus
Topic 1: Dissection practical - dissecting tissue relevant to subject specific disciplines, non-exhaustive examples might include: muscle for biomedical sciences, or fish gills for zoology students.

Topic 2: Immunological Assays and immunostaining

Topic 3: Protein Extraction and purification

Topic 4: Western Blotting

Topic 5: Cell Biology Techniques - for example treatment of cell cultures with pharmacological agents and plate based assays.

Topic 6: RNA Extraction. Covering topics such as theory of extraction protocols, RNA quality control and CDNA library creation

Topic 7: Reporter Gene Systems. Use of reporter gene systems in model organisms, such as but not included to plants

Topic 8: Quantitative RNA methods to tackle biological problems. Covering topics such as, but not limited to qPCR, RNAseq.

Topic 9: Cell Imaging. Covering topics such as fluorescent cell imaging


Statistical, data interpretation & data visualisation skills to be implemented may include topics such as (but not limited to):


Topic 1: Data visualisation

Topic 2: t-tests

Topic 3: ANOVA

Topic 4: Correlation

Topic 5: Linear regression

Topic 6: Chi-square

Topic 7: Non-parametric tests
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching Method 1

Lectures: Synchronous research focused lectures will cover introductory material and context to the practical skills and application of taught & experimental skills. Also incorporate application of numeracy & wider transferable skills to practical problem solving.

Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 2

Laboratory Work: F2F practical sessions designed to develop & enhance laboratory/experimental skills, including group working.
Demonstrators provide real-time feedback in laboratory practicals.

Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 3

Interactive Materials: Interactive virtual lab resources, simulations and videos that allow students to familiarise themselves with different lab skills and use equipment and scientific procedures within their own time and space, allowing for inclusivity & diversity.

Attendance Recorded: No, engagement monitored

Teaching Method 4

Asynchronous lecture recordings: Introduce applied quantitative skills to practical problem solving. To include a variety of data handling, statistical and data visualisation methodologies.

Attendance Recorded: No, engagement monitored

Teaching Method 5

Workshop Sessions: Academic led sessions that support problem-based learning approach on implementing data analysis, interpretation and visualisation skills. During the workshops, students may engage in smaller groups discussions and research activities on a specific topic related to the module content. Students will be assigned to smaller breakout groups within a larger computer-based teaching room. These comprise multiple sessions of active learning which focus on the assessment tasks/real world research, data analysis and simulations which will be delivered in a computer practical format.
Formative feedback is given to students in assessment workshops. Demonstrators facilitate feedback, and peer learning. Demonstrators will provide real-time feedback in assessment workshops. Students will also use online discussion boards both within and outside the session.

Attendance Recorded: Yes

The student directed learning element of the module will involve directed reading, completion of workbooks, accessing online resources, searching the literature and critically appraising articles. This will require adaptability & organisational skills.

Liverpool Curriculum and the Liverpool Hallmarks are at the centre of this module as evidenced by the cohesive research connected programme we have designed where learning outcomes will be evaluated with authentic assessments that directly relate to activities performed by professional experts in the field. This module contributes to programmes which are specifically designed to support students for future careers in Biosciences:

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists in the breadth of fields of life sciences to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with evidence-based publications of recent clinical, biotechnological and scientific research and application-based conceptualisation, where wider application of practical skills will be demonstrated. Practical tailored to specific research areas of interest, allowing interaction with world class researchers at the fore of scientific breakthrough and development to tackle biological, medical and technological challenges.

Inclusivity and accessibility: Development of practical experience in order to be accessible and inclusive for all individuals. Self-directed learning, using interactive resources will allow students to prepare for sessions and gain understanding of practical techniques before attending. Resource templates use accessible design schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans.

Active learning: Practical and experimental techniques within the biosciences are paramount to active learning through observation, skill acquisition and application. Continual feedback provided to students by staff, demonstrators and peers alike allow students to assess the extent of their learning and continually develop. Collaborative discussion and interpretation of practical methods and their application to wider science fosters deeper learning. Furthermore, group working in diverse teams of students from across the department allow students to gain insights in to broader perspectives and communicate findings from a multidisciplinary perspective.

Authentic assessment: There are three assessment components. The experimental design assessment requires students showcase their aptitude for practical skills and experimental design, continual learning, data analyses and visualisation and development and appreciation of the theoretical principles applied to Biosciences challenges. Online computational assessment will allow students to implement theoretical knowledge of quantitative biology and computational skills that supplement experimental practices, in order to tackle scientific problems related to wider fields of Biosciences. The use of student derived data to problem solve will be representative of real-world analytical techniques required in most career pathways. The Written scientific report is highly authentic for practical application and offers a comprehensive assessment of specialist knowledge and understanding of practical skills, the methodological processes and how they may interlink, whilst promoting presentation in a concise manner.

Confidence: Confidence is developed continuously throughout the module. Lectures are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. Practical sessions involve collaborative groupwork and experimental learning. Learners work as part of a team to plan and carry out complex technical work, under expert supervision. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise. Successfully completing a practical session builds confidence in technical skills and provides students with an awareness of good lab practice, risk assessment and safety when working in a practical environment.

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. Learners have access to advanced digital resources, programmes and analytical tools that will assist in the undertaking of data analyses. These are used as part of both lab based practical analyses and independent learning to consolidate practical and theoretical knowledge. Digital technology is embedded into practical teaching with the use of experimental applications, methodologies and computational practices that learners can explore in their own time. Furthermore, physical workshops will allow students to showcase their understand and application of quantitative tools and statistical methodologies for each of their collected datasets. Assessment activity also required students to develop competency with digital technology in order to effectively analyse data, communicate findings and present ideas/concepts.

Global citizenship: Biosciences is a globally connected professional community. Learning and assessment activities embed values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation and use scientific cases of diverse and underrepresented communities, focus on sustainable practices within the lab and field environment, whilst focusing on wider international collaboration in order to achieve goals. There is a strong ethical focus within the school that empowers learners to take personal responsibility for human impact of their actions, with focus on practical related ethics.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via three assessment components.
Variety of modes of assessment are employed keeping in view inclusivity and diversity.

The mode of assessments include:

SAQ exam – online, SAS Managed. Computer Assessment based on Campus (40%). Resit allowed. Students will use advanced digital resources, programmes and analytical tools to assist in data analyses. (Digital fluency and Authentic assessment- Liverpool Curriculum).

Group Scientific Research output (20%) based on skills acquired in practical sessions, (Authentic assessment- Liverpool Curriculum). Potential for negotiated assessment to include: conference style poster presentation, oral presentation, written scientific report performed as a group to showcase experimental design, knowledge application, quantitative data analyses and research communications. Resit allowed.

Written Individual Scientific Report: (weighting 40%) 1500 word written report detailing experimental processes, methodologies, theoretical knowledge and data analyses undertaken within practical sessions (Research connected teaching - Liverpool Curriculum). Resit allowed

Formative feedback is given to students in assessment workshops. Demonstrators facilitate feedback, and peer learning. Demonstrators will provide real-time feedback in assessment workshops.
Demonstrators also provide real-time feedback in laboratory practicals.

Feedback will be provided to all assessments. Pass mark for all assessments is 40%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

Resit strategy: Resit opportunity will be given to the assessments specified where a resit is available and will have similar format and content as the original assessment, but with substantial revision required and will be submitted during the reassessment window and capped at 40% (pass mark).

Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment. Details on the assessments are on the table below.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Notes

Overview

Overview
This practical module aims to enhance and develop practical and analytical skills related to the Biosciences by building on experiences gained in previous practical modules. This module will expand on core techniques and practical skills introduced at previous levels of study and develop quantitative and qualitative research practices, data handling and critical analyses applied to experimental research problems. Students will learn the fundamental principles of experimental design and the essential statistical and mathematical methods necessary for assessment and communication of practical experiments. Within this module, students will be able to tailor their practical learning to focus on research problems associated with their programme of study or fields of interest.

The module comprises of physical practical sessions alongside introductory plenary lectures and workshops, using active-learning delivery methods to ensure students can understand, synthesise, evaluate and communicate their research findings.  This practical will be assessed via three methods: 1) a computer-based assessment to assess understanding of quantitative and computational skills, 2) a group research output focused on experimental design and 3) analyses of data and a written scientific report to assess communication of research outputs through scientific writing.
Educational Aims
The aims of this module are:

1. To develop and enhance experimental and practical skills relevant to the disciplines of Biosciences, including key experimental design principles.

2. To enhance students’ acquisition of fundamental research skills; including information gathering, scientific data collection, report writing and statistical analyses.

3. To enable students to analyse and interpret scientific data from different types of experiment and communicate the results

4. To enhance digital fluency, including development of coding skills, data visualisation and computational analyses.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This practical skills module is designed to give you hands-on experience in a range of essential laboratory techniques, building on foundational practical skills developed in the first year of study. From protein purification to nucleic acid quantification and the use of general model systems, this module covers a variety of techniques that you need to further your practical development within the breadth of the Biosciences disciplines.

Through a series of interactive experimental sessions and live synchronous workshops, you will gain practical experience in a variety of analytical and quantitative experimental practices. You will also learn the underpinning knowledge behind some of the methodologies and the intricacies of experimental design, all the while supplementing your wider theoretical learning through experimental application of techniques to tackle problems across the Biosciences disciplines. Students will learn how to analyse collected data and communicate the findings effectively, with the opportunity to apply your newly acquired skills to research projects tailored towards your programme and fields of interest. This module will be assessed via a computer-based assessment to assess understanding of quantitative and computational skills, a group research output focused on experimental design and a written scientific report to assess communication of research outputs through scientific writing.

This module will expand your laboratory skills and allow the advancement of practical experiences in a range of essential techniques and equip you with the skills and knowledge you need to prepare you for your honours dissertation projects.
Outline Syllabus
Topic 1: Dissection practical - dissecting tissue relevant to subject specific disciplines, non-exhaustive examples might include: muscle for biomedical sciences, or fish gills for zoology students.

Topic 2: Immunological Assays and immunostaining

Topic 3: Protein Extraction and purification

Topic 4: Western Blotting

Topic 5: Cell Biology Techniques - for example treatment of cell cultures with pharmacological agents and plate based assays.

Topic 6: RNA Extraction. Covering topics such as theory of extraction protocols, RNA quality control and CDNA library creation

Topic 7: Reporter Gene Systems. Use of reporter gene systems in model organisms, such as but not included to plants

Topic 8: Quantitative RNA methods to tackle biological problems. Covering topics such as, but not limited to qPCR, RNAseq.

Topic 9: Cell Imaging. Covering topics such as fluorescent cell imaging


Statistical, data interpretation & data visualisation skills to be implemented may include topics such as (but not limited to):


Topic 1: Data visualisation

Topic 2: t-tests

Topic 3: ANOVA

Topic 4: Correlation

Topic 5: Linear regression

Topic 6: Chi-square

Topic 7: Non-parametric tests
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching Method 1

Lectures: Synchronous research focused lectures will cover introductory material and context to the practical skills and application of taught & experimental skills. Also incorporate application of numeracy & wider transferable skills to practical problem solving.

Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 2

Laboratory Work: F2F practical sessions designed to develop & enhance laboratory/experimental skills, including group working.
Demonstrators provide real-time feedback in laboratory practicals.

Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 3

Interactive Materials: Interactive virtual lab resources, simulations and videos that allow students to familiarise themselves with different lab skills and use equipment and scientific procedures within their own time and space, allowing for inclusivity & diversity.

Attendance Recorded: No, engagement monitored

Teaching Method 4

Asynchronous lecture recordings: Introduce applied quantitative skills to practical problem solving. To include a variety of data handling, statistical and data visualisation methodologies.

Attendance Recorded: No, engagement monitored

Teaching Method 5

Workshop Sessions: Academic led sessions that support problem-based learning approach on implementing data analysis, interpretation and visualisation skills. During the workshops, students may engage in smaller groups discussions and research activities on a specific topic related to the module content. Students will be assigned to smaller breakout groups within a larger computer-based teaching room. These comprise multiple sessions of active learning which focus on the assessment tasks/real world research, data analysis and simulations which will be delivered in a computer practical format.
Formative feedback is given to students in assessment workshops. Demonstrators facilitate feedback, and peer learning. Demonstrators will provide real-time feedback in assessment workshops. Students will also use online discussion boards both within and outside the session.

Attendance Recorded: Yes

The student directed learning element of the module will involve directed reading, completion of workbooks, accessing online resources, searching the literature and critically appraising articles. This will require adaptability & organisational skills.

Liverpool Curriculum and the Liverpool Hallmarks are at the centre of this module as evidenced by the cohesive research connected programme we have designed where learning outcomes will be evaluated with authentic assessments that directly relate to activities performed by professional experts in the field. This module contributes to programmes which are specifically designed to support students for future careers in Biosciences:

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists in the breadth of fields of life sciences to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with evidence-based publications of recent clinical, biotechnological and scientific research and application-based conceptualisation, where wider application of practical skills will be demonstrated. Practical tailored to specific research areas of interest, allowing interaction with world class researchers at the fore of scientific breakthrough and development to tackle biological, medical and technological challenges.

Inclusivity and accessibility: Development of practical experience in order to be accessible and inclusive for all individuals. Self-directed learning, using interactive resources will allow students to prepare for sessions and gain understanding of practical techniques before attending. Resource templates use accessible design schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans.

Active learning: Practical and experimental techniques within the biosciences are paramount to active learning through observation, skill acquisition and application. Continual feedback provided to students by staff, demonstrators and peers alike allow students to assess the extent of their learning and continually develop. Collaborative discussion and interpretation of practical methods and their application to wider science fosters deeper learning. Furthermore, group working in diverse teams of students from across the department allow students to gain insights in to broader perspectives and communicate findings from a multidisciplinary perspective.

Authentic assessment: There are three assessment components. The experimental design assessment requires students showcase their aptitude for practical skills and experimental design, continual learning, data analyses and visualisation and development and appreciation of the theoretical principles applied to Biosciences challenges. Online computational assessment will allow students to implement theoretical knowledge of quantitative biology and computational skills that supplement experimental practices, in order to tackle scientific problems related to wider fields of Biosciences. The use of student derived data to problem solve will be representative of real-world analytical techniques required in most career pathways. The Written scientific report is highly authentic for practical application and offers a comprehensive assessment of specialist knowledge and understanding of practical skills, the methodological processes and how they may interlink, whilst promoting presentation in a concise manner.

Confidence: Confidence is developed continuously throughout the module. Lectures are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. Practical sessions involve collaborative groupwork and experimental learning. Learners work as part of a team to plan and carry out complex technical work, under expert supervision. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise. Successfully completing a practical session builds confidence in technical skills and provides students with an awareness of good lab practice, risk assessment and safety when working in a practical environment.

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. Learners have access to advanced digital resources, programmes and analytical tools that will assist in the undertaking of data analyses. These are used as part of both lab based practical analyses and independent learning to consolidate practical and theoretical knowledge. Digital technology is embedded into practical teaching with the use of experimental applications, methodologies and computational practices that learners can explore in their own time. Furthermore, physical workshops will allow students to showcase their understand and application of quantitative tools and statistical methodologies for each of their collected datasets. Assessment activity also required students to develop competency with digital technology in order to effectively analyse data, communicate findings and present ideas/concepts.

Global citizenship: Biosciences is a globally connected professional community. Learning and assessment activities embed values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation and use scientific cases of diverse and underrepresented communities, focus on sustainable practices within the lab and field environment, whilst focusing on wider international collaboration in order to achieve goals. There is a strong ethical focus within the school that empowers learners to take personal responsibility for human impact of their actions, with focus on practical related ethics.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via three assessment components.
Variety of modes of assessment are employed keeping in view inclusivity and diversity.

The mode of assessments include:

SAQ exam – online, SAS Managed. Computer Assessment based on Campus (40%). Resit allowed. Students will use advanced digital resources, programmes and analytical tools to assist in data analyses. (Digital fluency and Authentic assessment- Liverpool Curriculum).

Group Scientific Research output (20%) based on skills acquired in practical sessions, (Authentic assessment- Liverpool Curriculum). Potential for negotiated assessment to include: conference style poster presentation, oral presentation, written scientific report performed as a group to showcase experimental design, knowledge application, quantitative data analyses and research communications. Resit allowed.

Written Individual Scientific Report: (weighting 40%) 1500 word written report detailing experimental processes, methodologies, theoretical knowledge and data analyses undertaken within practical sessions (Research connected teaching - Liverpool Curriculum). Resit allowed

Formative feedback is given to students in assessment workshops. Demonstrators facilitate feedback, and peer learning. Demonstrators will provide real-time feedback in assessment workshops.
Demonstrators also provide real-time feedback in laboratory practicals.

Feedback will be provided to all assessments. Pass mark for all assessments is 40%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

Resit strategy: Resit opportunity will be given to the assessments specified where a resit is available and will have similar format and content as the original assessment, but with substantial revision required and will be submitted during the reassessment window and capped at 40% (pass mark).

Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment. Details on the assessments are on the table below.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Notes

Overview

Overview
This practical module aims to enhance and develop practical and analytical skills related to the Biosciences by building on experiences gained in previous practical modules. This module will expand on core techniques and practical skills introduced at previous levels of study and develop quantitative and qualitative research practices, data handling and critical analyses applied to experimental research problems. Students will learn the fundamental principles of experimental design and the essential statistical and mathematical methods necessary for assessment and communication of practical experiments. Within this module, students will be able to tailor their practical learning to focus on research problems associated with their programme of study or fields of interest.

The module comprises of physical practical sessions alongside introductory plenary lectures and workshops, using active-learning delivery methods to ensure students can understand, synthesise, evaluate and communicate their research findings.  This practical will be assessed via three methods: 1) a computer-based assessment to assess understanding of quantitative and computational skills, 2) a group research output focused on experimental design and 3) analyses of data and a written scientific report to assess communication of research outputs through scientific writing.
Educational Aims
The aims of this module are:

1. To develop and enhance experimental and practical skills relevant to the disciplines of Biosciences, including key experimental design principles.

2. To enhance students’ acquisition of fundamental research skills; including information gathering, scientific data collection, report writing and statistical analyses.

3. To enable students to analyse and interpret scientific data from different types of experiment and communicate the results

4. To enhance digital fluency, including development of coding skills, data visualisation and computational analyses.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This practical skills module is designed to give you hands-on experience in a range of essential laboratory techniques, building on foundational practical skills developed in the first year of study. From protein purification to nucleic acid quantification and the use of general model systems, this module covers a variety of techniques that you need to further your practical development within the breadth of the Biosciences disciplines.

Through a series of interactive experimental sessions and live synchronous workshops, you will gain practical experience in a variety of analytical and quantitative experimental practices. You will also learn the underpinning knowledge behind some of the methodologies and the intricacies of experimental design, all the while supplementing your wider theoretical learning through experimental application of techniques to tackle problems across the Biosciences disciplines. Students will learn how to analyse collected data and communicate the findings effectively, with the opportunity to apply your newly acquired skills to research projects tailored towards your programme and fields of interest. This module will be assessed via a computer-based assessment to assess understanding of quantitative and computational skills, a group research output focused on experimental design and a written scientific report to assess communication of research outputs through scientific writing.

This module will expand your laboratory skills and allow the advancement of practical experiences in a range of essential techniques and equip you with the skills and knowledge you need to prepare you for your honours dissertation projects.
Outline Syllabus
Topic 1: Dissection practical - dissecting tissue relevant to subject specific disciplines, non-exhaustive examples might include: muscle for biomedical sciences, or fish gills for zoology students.

Topic 2: Immunological Assays and immunostaining

Topic 3: Protein Extraction and purification

Topic 4: Western Blotting

Topic 5: Cell Biology Techniques - for example treatment of cell cultures with pharmacological agents and plate based assays.

Topic 6: RNA Extraction. Covering topics such as theory of extraction protocols, RNA quality control and CDNA library creation

Topic 7: Reporter Gene Systems. Use of reporter gene systems in model organisms, such as but not included to plants

Topic 8: Quantitative RNA methods to tackle biological problems. Covering topics such as, but not limited to qPCR, RNAseq.

Topic 9: Cell Imaging. Covering topics such as fluorescent cell imaging


Statistical, data interpretation & data visualisation skills to be implemented may include topics such as (but not limited to):


Topic 1: Data visualisation

Topic 2: t-tests

Topic 3: ANOVA

Topic 4: Correlation

Topic 5: Linear regression

Topic 6: Chi-square

Topic 7: Non-parametric tests
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching Method 1

Lectures: Synchronous research focused lectures will cover introductory material and context to the practical skills and application of taught & experimental skills. Also incorporate application of numeracy & wider transferable skills to practical problem solving.

Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 2

Laboratory Work: F2F practical sessions designed to develop & enhance laboratory/experimental skills, including group working.
Demonstrators provide real-time feedback in laboratory practicals.

Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 3

Interactive Materials: Interactive virtual lab resources, simulations and videos that allow students to familiarise themselves with different lab skills and use equipment and scientific procedures within their own time and space, allowing for inclusivity & diversity.

Attendance Recorded: No, engagement monitored

Teaching Method 4

Asynchronous lecture recordings: Introduce applied quantitative skills to practical problem solving. To include a variety of data handling, statistical and data visualisation methodologies.

Attendance Recorded: No, engagement monitored

Teaching Method 5

Workshop Sessions: Academic led sessions that support problem-based learning approach on implementing data analysis, interpretation and visualisation skills. During the workshops, students may engage in smaller groups discussions and research activities on a specific topic related to the module content. Students will be assigned to smaller breakout groups within a larger computer-based teaching room. These comprise multiple sessions of active learning which focus on the assessment tasks/real world research, data analysis and simulations which will be delivered in a computer practical format.
Formative feedback is given to students in assessment workshops. Demonstrators facilitate feedback, and peer learning. Demonstrators will provide real-time feedback in assessment workshops. Students will also use online discussion boards both within and outside the session.

Attendance Recorded: Yes

The student directed learning element of the module will involve directed reading, completion of workbooks, accessing online resources, searching the literature and critically appraising articles. This will require adaptability & organisational skills.

Liverpool Curriculum and the Liverpool Hallmarks are at the centre of this module as evidenced by the cohesive research connected programme we have designed where learning outcomes will be evaluated with authentic assessments that directly relate to activities performed by professional experts in the field. This module contributes to programmes which are specifically designed to support students for future careers in Biosciences:

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists in the breadth of fields of life sciences to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with evidence-based publications of recent clinical, biotechnological and scientific research and application-based conceptualisation, where wider application of practical skills will be demonstrated. Practical tailored to specific research areas of interest, allowing interaction with world class researchers at the fore of scientific breakthrough and development to tackle biological, medical and technological challenges.

Inclusivity and accessibility: Development of practical experience in order to be accessible and inclusive for all individuals. Self-directed learning, using interactive resources will allow students to prepare for sessions and gain understanding of practical techniques before attending. Resource templates use accessible design schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans.

Active learning: Practical and experimental techniques within the biosciences are paramount to active learning through observation, skill acquisition and application. Continual feedback provided to students by staff, demonstrators and peers alike allow students to assess the extent of their learning and continually develop. Collaborative discussion and interpretation of practical methods and their application to wider science fosters deeper learning. Furthermore, group working in diverse teams of students from across the department allow students to gain insights in to broader perspectives and communicate findings from a multidisciplinary perspective.

Authentic assessment: There are three assessment components. The experimental design assessment requires students showcase their aptitude for practical skills and experimental design, continual learning, data analyses and visualisation and development and appreciation of the theoretical principles applied to Biosciences challenges. Online computational assessment will allow students to implement theoretical knowledge of quantitative biology and computational skills that supplement experimental practices, in order to tackle scientific problems related to wider fields of Biosciences. The use of student derived data to problem solve will be representative of real-world analytical techniques required in most career pathways. The Written scientific report is highly authentic for practical application and offers a comprehensive assessment of specialist knowledge and understanding of practical skills, the methodological processes and how they may interlink, whilst promoting presentation in a concise manner.

Confidence: Confidence is developed continuously throughout the module. Lectures are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. Practical sessions involve collaborative groupwork and experimental learning. Learners work as part of a team to plan and carry out complex technical work, under expert supervision. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise. Successfully completing a practical session builds confidence in technical skills and provides students with an awareness of good lab practice, risk assessment and safety when working in a practical environment.

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. Learners have access to advanced digital resources, programmes and analytical tools that will assist in the undertaking of data analyses. These are used as part of both lab based practical analyses and independent learning to consolidate practical and theoretical knowledge. Digital technology is embedded into practical teaching with the use of experimental applications, methodologies and computational practices that learners can explore in their own time. Furthermore, physical workshops will allow students to showcase their understand and application of quantitative tools and statistical methodologies for each of their collected datasets. Assessment activity also required students to develop competency with digital technology in order to effectively analyse data, communicate findings and present ideas/concepts.

Global citizenship: Biosciences is a globally connected professional community. Learning and assessment activities embed values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation and use scientific cases of diverse and underrepresented communities, focus on sustainable practices within the lab and field environment, whilst focusing on wider international collaboration in order to achieve goals. There is a strong ethical focus within the school that empowers learners to take personal responsibility for human impact of their actions, with focus on practical related ethics.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via three assessment components.
Variety of modes of assessment are employed keeping in view inclusivity and diversity.

The mode of assessments include:

SAQ exam – online, SAS Managed. Computer Assessment based on Campus (40%). Resit allowed. Students will use advanced digital resources, programmes and analytical tools to assist in data analyses. (Digital fluency and Authentic assessment- Liverpool Curriculum).

Group Scientific Research output (20%) based on skills acquired in practical sessions, (Authentic assessment- Liverpool Curriculum). Potential for negotiated assessment to include: conference style poster presentation, oral presentation, written scientific report performed as a group to showcase experimental design, knowledge application, quantitative data analyses and research communications. Resit allowed.

Written Individual Scientific Report: (weighting 40%) 1500 word written report detailing experimental processes, methodologies, theoretical knowledge and data analyses undertaken within practical sessions (Research connected teaching - Liverpool Curriculum). Resit allowed

Formative feedback is given to students in assessment workshops. Demonstrators facilitate feedback, and peer learning. Demonstrators will provide real-time feedback in assessment workshops.
Demonstrators also provide real-time feedback in laboratory practicals.

Feedback will be provided to all assessments. Pass mark for all assessments is 40%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

Resit strategy: Resit opportunity will be given to the assessments specified where a resit is available and will have similar format and content as the original assessment, but with substantial revision required and will be submitted during the reassessment window and capped at 40% (pass mark).

Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment. Details on the assessments are on the table below.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

BIOS203
Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2025,

Overview

Overview
This practical module aims to enhance and develop practical and analytical skills related to the Biosciences by building on experiences gained in previous practical modules. This module will expand on core techniques and practical skills introduced at previous levels of study and develop quantitative and qualitative research practices, data handling and critical analyses applied to experimental research problems. Students will learn the fundamental principles of experimental design and the essential statistical and mathematical methods necessary for assessment and communication of practical experiments. Within this module, students will be able to tailor their practical learning to focus on research problems associated with their programme of study or fields of interest.

The module comprises of physical practical sessions alongside introductory plenary lectures and workshops, using active-learning delivery methods to ensure students can understand, synthesise, evaluate and communicate their research findings.  This practical will be assessed via three methods: 1) a computer-based assessment to assess understanding of quantitative and computational skills, 2) a group research output focused on experimental design and 3) analyses of data and a written scientific report to assess communication of research outputs through scientific writing.
Educational Aims
The aims of this module are:

1. To develop and enhance experimental and practical skills relevant to the disciplines of Biosciences, including key experimental design principles.

2. To enhance students’ acquisition of fundamental research skills; including information gathering, scientific data collection, report writing and statistical analyses.

3. To enable students to analyse and interpret scientific data from different types of experiment and communicate the results

4. To enhance digital fluency, including development of coding skills, data visualisation and computational analyses.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This practical skills module is designed to give you hands-on experience in a range of essential laboratory techniques, building on foundational practical skills developed in the first year of study. From protein purification to nucleic acid quantification and the use of general model systems, this module covers a variety of techniques that you need to further your practical development within the breadth of the Biosciences disciplines.

Through a series of interactive experimental sessions and live synchronous workshops, you will gain practical experience in a variety of analytical and quantitative experimental practices. You will also learn the underpinning knowledge behind some of the methodologies and the intricacies of experimental design, all the while supplementing your wider theoretical learning through experimental application of techniques to tackle problems across the Biosciences disciplines. Students will learn how to analyse collected data and communicate the findings effectively, with the opportunity to apply your newly acquired skills to research projects tailored towards your programme and fields of interest. This module will be assessed via a computer-based assessment to assess understanding of quantitative and computational skills, a group research output focused on experimental design and a written scientific report to assess communication of research outputs through scientific writing.

This module will expand your laboratory skills and allow the advancement of practical experiences in a range of essential techniques and equip you with the skills and knowledge you need to prepare you for your honours dissertation projects.
Outline Syllabus
Topic 1: Dissection practical - dissecting tissue relevant to subject specific disciplines, non-exhaustive examples might include: muscle for biomedical sciences, or fish gills for zoology students.

Topic 2: Immunological Assays and immunostaining

Topic 3: Protein Extraction and purification

Topic 4: Western Blotting

Topic 5: Cell Biology Techniques - for example treatment of cell cultures with pharmacological agents and plate based assays.

Topic 6: RNA Extraction. Covering topics such as theory of extraction protocols, RNA quality control and CDNA library creation

Topic 7: Reporter Gene Systems. Use of reporter gene systems in model organisms, such as but not included to plants

Topic 8: Quantitative RNA methods to tackle biological problems. Covering topics such as, but not limited to qPCR, RNAseq.

Topic 9: Cell Imaging. Covering topics such as fluorescent cell imaging


Statistical, data interpretation & data visualisation skills to be implemented may include topics such as (but not limited to):


Topic 1: Data visualisation

Topic 2: t-tests

Topic 3: ANOVA

Topic 4: Correlation

Topic 5: Linear regression

Topic 6: Chi-square

Topic 7: Non-parametric tests
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching Method 1

Lectures: Synchronous research focused lectures will cover introductory material and context to the practical skills and application of taught & experimental skills. Also incorporate application of numeracy & wider transferable skills to practical problem solving.

Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 2

Laboratory Work: F2F practical sessions designed to develop & enhance laboratory/experimental skills, including group working.
Demonstrators provide real-time feedback in laboratory practicals.

Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 3

Interactive Materials: Interactive virtual lab resources, simulations and videos that allow students to familiarise themselves with different lab skills and use equipment and scientific procedures within their own time and space, allowing for inclusivity & diversity.

Attendance Recorded: No, engagement monitored

Teaching Method 4

Asynchronous lecture recordings: Introduce applied quantitative skills to practical problem solving. To include a variety of data handling, statistical and data visualisation methodologies.

Attendance Recorded: No, engagement monitored

Teaching Method 5

Workshop Sessions: Academic led sessions that support problem-based learning approach on implementing data analysis, interpretation and visualisation skills. During the workshops, students may engage in smaller groups discussions and research activities on a specific topic related to the module content. Students will be assigned to smaller breakout groups within a larger computer-based teaching room. These comprise multiple sessions of active learning which focus on the assessment tasks/real world research, data analysis and simulations which will be delivered in a computer practical format.
Formative feedback is given to students in assessment workshops. Demonstrators facilitate feedback, and peer learning. Demonstrators will provide real-time feedback in assessment workshops. Students will also use online discussion boards both within and outside the session.

Attendance Recorded: Yes

The student directed learning element of the module will involve directed reading, completion of workbooks, accessing online resources, searching the literature and critically appraising articles. This will require adaptability & organisational skills.

Liverpool Curriculum and the Liverpool Hallmarks are at the centre of this module as evidenced by the cohesive research connected programme we have designed where learning outcomes will be evaluated with authentic assessments that directly relate to activities performed by professional experts in the field. This module contributes to programmes which are specifically designed to support students for future careers in Biosciences:

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists in the breadth of fields of life sciences to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with evidence-based publications of recent clinical, biotechnological and scientific research and application-based conceptualisation, where wider application of practical skills will be demonstrated. Practical tailored to specific research areas of interest, allowing interaction with world class researchers at the fore of scientific breakthrough and development to tackle biological, medical and technological challenges.

Inclusivity and accessibility: Development of practical experience in order to be accessible and inclusive for all individuals. Self-directed learning, using interactive resources will allow students to prepare for sessions and gain understanding of practical techniques before attending. Resource templates use accessible design schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans.

Active learning: Practical and experimental techniques within the biosciences are paramount to active learning through observation, skill acquisition and application. Continual feedback provided to students by staff, demonstrators and peers alike allow students to assess the extent of their learning and continually develop. Collaborative discussion and interpretation of practical methods and their application to wider science fosters deeper learning. Furthermore, group working in diverse teams of students from across the department allow students to gain insights in to broader perspectives and communicate findings from a multidisciplinary perspective.

Authentic assessment: There are three assessment components. The experimental design assessment requires students showcase their aptitude for practical skills and experimental design, continual learning, data analyses and visualisation and development and appreciation of the theoretical principles applied to Biosciences challenges. Online computational assessment will allow students to implement theoretical knowledge of quantitative biology and computational skills that supplement experimental practices, in order to tackle scientific problems related to wider fields of Biosciences. The use of student derived data to problem solve will be representative of real-world analytical techniques required in most career pathways. The Written scientific report is highly authentic for practical application and offers a comprehensive assessment of specialist knowledge and understanding of practical skills, the methodological processes and how they may interlink, whilst promoting presentation in a concise manner.

Confidence: Confidence is developed continuously throughout the module. Lectures are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. Practical sessions involve collaborative groupwork and experimental learning. Learners work as part of a team to plan and carry out complex technical work, under expert supervision. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise. Successfully completing a practical session builds confidence in technical skills and provides students with an awareness of good lab practice, risk assessment and safety when working in a practical environment.

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. Learners have access to advanced digital resources, programmes and analytical tools that will assist in the undertaking of data analyses. These are used as part of both lab based practical analyses and independent learning to consolidate practical and theoretical knowledge. Digital technology is embedded into practical teaching with the use of experimental applications, methodologies and computational practices that learners can explore in their own time. Furthermore, physical workshops will allow students to showcase their understand and application of quantitative tools and statistical methodologies for each of their collected datasets. Assessment activity also required students to develop competency with digital technology in order to effectively analyse data, communicate findings and present ideas/concepts.

Global citizenship: Biosciences is a globally connected professional community. Learning and assessment activities embed values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation and use scientific cases of diverse and underrepresented communities, focus on sustainable practices within the lab and field environment, whilst focusing on wider international collaboration in order to achieve goals. There is a strong ethical focus within the school that empowers learners to take personal responsibility for human impact of their actions, with focus on practical related ethics.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via three assessment components.
Variety of modes of assessment are employed keeping in view inclusivity and diversity.

The mode of assessments include:

SAQ exam – online, SAS Managed. Computer Assessment based on Campus (40%). Resit allowed. Students will use advanced digital resources, programmes and analytical tools to assist in data analyses. (Digital fluency and Authentic assessment- Liverpool Curriculum).

Group Scientific Research output (20%) based on skills acquired in practical sessions, (Authentic assessment- Liverpool Curriculum). Potential for negotiated assessment to include: conference style poster presentation, oral presentation, written scientific report performed as a group to showcase experimental design, knowledge application, quantitative data analyses and research communications. Resit allowed.

Written Individual Scientific Report: (weighting 40%) 1500 word written report detailing experimental processes, methodologies, theoretical knowledge and data analyses undertaken within practical sessions (Research connected teaching - Liverpool Curriculum). Resit allowed

Formative feedback is given to students in assessment workshops. Demonstrators facilitate feedback, and peer learning. Demonstrators will provide real-time feedback in assessment workshops.
Demonstrators also provide real-time feedback in laboratory practicals.

Feedback will be provided to all assessments. Pass mark for all assessments is 40%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

Resit strategy: Resit opportunity will be given to the assessments specified where a resit is available and will have similar format and content as the original assessment, but with substantial revision required and will be submitted during the reassessment window and capped at 40% (pass mark).

Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment. Details on the assessments are on the table below.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
